Posted By: ThinkOriginal (1/28/2013 9:27:00 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I think this card is much better for it's format than it is for it's card. It's an average beater with a lifegain tacked on (a nice bonus) and a small beater left over for you. It's true that flicker effects can add up on him and really flip a game, but I'm unsure that 5 life + 3/3 for a card, even if that card is cheap is that mind-bogglingly good. It's good for sure! But.. I think it has more to do with it's standard environment.   
  
JMS is brutal in \*any\* environment, and one could say the same for Baneslayer.   
  
That said, they have printed a clear response to him: [Boros Reckoner](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Boros Reckoner)  
You get your choice of killing him without problem, killing him and hitting the opponent for 5 (countering the life gain) or possibly other options.   
  
I wish I could give a 4.3, I'll go with 4.5?
posts.html:

JMS is brutal in *any* environment, and one could say the same for Baneslayer.

posts.post_content:
I call power creep. Overpowered card due to the simple fact that it read "leaves the battlefield" instead of "dies". Shouldn't be splashable either. The fact that this is seeing play in 75% of the top decks is rediculous.  
  
Make it 3GG and change the "leaves battlefield" clause to "dies" and it would be at least a little closer to balanced.  
  
  
  
That said, I do not hate-rate cards because I don't like them or they are OP. 4.5/5

posts.post_content: This card is stupidly good because of the meta it was brought about in. And I do mean "stupidly". I know they really wanted to push the blink mechanic but in the process they created a standard warping monster. Most decks at the moment are either midrange that utilizes this, Control that tries to stop it from being played, or Zombies which tries to minimize its impact. Gaining 5 life slows down most aggro decks for you to be able to set up your wincon (if this dude isn't it already). The 3/3 beast is really just a chump blocker, but you get it when it *leaves the battlefield*. Not dies. If it hits, there is no way to get rid of it without it making the token. That means you can drop any boardwipe of your choice and get instant board advantage. That paired with easy splashing, aggressive power and a toughness that keeps it out of reach of Pillar of Flame makes this one of the most pivotal cards in standard at the moment. Unless Gatecrash has an easy was to counter activated abiliti... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

posts.post_content:
3,9? You have got to be kidding me. This is hands down the most powerful card in Standard, and almost all deck archetypes splash green to run four of these. Why? Because Standard has NO good answers to it, apart from counterspells, and counterspells are nerfed this season with [Mana Leak](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mana Leak) gone and [Cavern of Souls](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Cavern of Souls) around. If you play it and it isn't countered, you WILL get your 5 life, your 5/3 and your 3/3 for 5 mana, and that's just if you don't abuse it with flickering shenanigans such as [Restoration Angel](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Restoration Angel) and [Cloudshift](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Cloudshift).  
  
Apart from counterspells, let's take a look at your options to get rid of this thing:  
  
\* Burn/removal/exile? You'll need to use two of them, and even then they still get 5 life. Exile is no more effective than burn/destroy, since the 3/3 spawns when Thragtusk "leaves the battlefield", not "dies".  
  
\* [Pacifism](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Pacifism) and the likes? No, because this often comes in decks wi... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

* Burn/removal/exile? You'll need to use two of them, and even then they still get 5 life. Exile is no more effective than burn/destroy, since the 3/3 spawns when Thragtusk "leaves the battlefield", not "dies".

Posted By: shotoku64 (1/3/2013 8:07:53 PM)

posts.post_content: Alright, clearly people have been hate-rating, but before you say it's sooo OP and continue to hate-rate, compare to [Thundermaw Hellkite](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Thundermaw Hellkite). Imagine you were trying to race the Hellkite with Thragtusk. Thundermaw swings a turn earlier, but Thragtusk gains you 5 life to make up for it. If you could block the Hellkite, you could kill it and get a 3/3, but it has flying. And if you had a flier the turn it came down, that creature is either dead or tapped for a turn. They both have etb abilities (maybe for flickering?) and they're almost on par with each other, even if this is more splashable. I'd give to edge to Hellkite because it's faster but Thragtusk is better for board presence. However, because Thundermaw Hellkite is a mythic and Thragtusk is a rare, Thragtusk is a very powerful card and is irritating if it resolves.
posts.html:
Alright, clearly people have been hate-rating, but before you say it's sooo OP and continue to hate-rate, compare to Thundermaw Hellkite. Imagine you were trying to race the Hellkite with Thragtusk. Thundermaw swings a turn earlier, but Thragtusk gains you 5 life to make up for it. If you could block the Hellkite, you could kill it and get a 3/3, but it has flying. And if you had a flier the turn it came down, that creature is either dead or tapped for a turn. They both have etb abilities (maybe for flickering?) and they're almost on par with each other, even if this is more splashable. I'd give to edge to Hellkite because it's faster but Thragtusk is better for board presence. However, because Thundermaw Hellkite is a mythic and Thragtusk is a rare, Thragtusk is a very powerful card and is irritating if it resolves.

posts.post_content:
I'm another of the opinion that "leaves the battlefield" was just outright unnecessary, and it should have been a "dies" trigger. You should not want to run something like Arrest over Oblivion Ring (that is, O-Ring is almost always better than Arrest, and that should be the case) just because Wizards decided to make a creature that made exiling just as bad as destruction.  
  
A dies trigger would not have changed much about the playability of this card - it'd just give you a few more options to prevent the token while also stopping the creature. As it stands, 5 life and forcing you to not just destroy it (or give up card advantage) would still have been played by a large number of decks.  
  
In terms of power it should have certainly been mythic; fortunately they didn't make it that way so people who actually want to play competitive can save a smidge of money (due to extra supply). Still... I won't be displeased when this rotates out.  
  
And yeah, it's obviously hate-rated. This... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:
I'm another of the opinion that "leaves the battlefield" was just outright unnecessary, and it should have been a "dies" trigger. You should not want to run something like Arrest over Oblivion Ring (that is, O-Ring is almost always better than Arrest, and that should be the case) just because Wizards decided to make a creature that made exiling just as bad as destruction.

A dies trigger would not have changed much about the playability of this card - it'd just give you a few more options to prevent the token while also stopping the creature. As it stands, 5 life and forcing you to not just destroy it (or give up card advantage) would still have been played by a large number of decks.

In terms of power it should have certainly been mythic; fortunately they didn't make it that way so people who actually want to play competitive can save a smidge of money (due to extra supply). Still... I won't be displeased when this rotates out.
